text: There was a man in the land of Uz whose name was Job. That man was blameless and upright and God-fearing and turning away from evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: And seven sons and three daughters were born to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his livestock came to be seven thousand sheep and goats and three thousand camels and five hundred pairs of oxen and five hundred female donkeys, and he had very many slaves, and that man was greater than all the people of the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: And his sons used to go and hold a feast at each other’s house on his day, and they would send, and they would invite their three sisters to eat and to drink with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then when the days of the feast had run their course, Job would send, and he would sanctify them. Thus he would arise early in the morning and offer burnt offerings according to the number of all of them, because Job thought, “Perhaps my children have sinned and cursed God in their heart.” This is what Job used to do all the time.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it happened one day that the sons of God came to present themselves before Yahweh, and Satan also came into their midst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Yahweh said to Satan, “From where have you come?”
Then Satan answered Yahweh and said, “From roaming on the earth and from walking about in it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Yahweh said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? Indeed, there is no one like him on the earth—a blameless man and upright and God-fearing and turning away from evil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Satan answered Yahweh and said, “Does Job fear God for nothing?
speaker: Narrator

text: Have you not put a fence around him and his household and around all that belongs to him on every side? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his livestock has increased in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But, on the other hand, stretch out your hand and touch all that belongs to him and see whether he will curse you to your face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Yahweh said to Satan, “Look, all that belongs to him is in your power. Only do not stretch out your hand against him.” So Satan went out from Yahweh’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: And then there was one day when his sons and his daughters were eating and drinking wine in their firstborn brother’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: And a messenger came to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing, and the female donkeys were feeding beside them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Sabeans attacked, and they took them, and they slew the servants by the edge of the sword. But I escaped, even I alone, to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While this one was still speaking, another came and said, “The fire of God fell from the heavens, and it blazed up against the sheep and goats and against the servants, and it consumed them. But I escaped, even I alone, to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While this one was still speaking, another came and said, “The Chaldeans formed three divisions, and they made a raid on the camels, and they carried them away, and they struck your servants by the edge of the sword, but I escaped, even I alone, to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: At the time this one was speaking, another came and said, “Your sons and your daughters were eating and drinking wine in their firstborn brother’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: And behold, a great wind came from across the desert, and it struck the four corners of the house so that it fell upon the young people, and they died. But I escaped, even I alone, to tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job arose and tore his outer garment and shaved his head; then he fell upon the ground and he worshiped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said, “Naked I came out from my mother’s womb, and naked I will return there. Yahweh gives, and Yahweh takes. Let Yahweh’s name be blessed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In all this, Job did not sin and did not charge God with wrongdoing.
speaker: Narrator

text: And then one day the sons of God came to present themselves before Yahweh, and Satan also came into their midst to present himself before Yahweh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Yahweh asked Satan, “From where have you come?”
And Satan answered Yahweh and said, “From roaming on the earth and from walking about in it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Yahweh asked Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job? Indeed, there is no one like him on the earth—a blameless man and upright and God-fearing and turning away from evil. And still he persists in his blamelessness even though you incited me against him to destroy him for nothing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Satan answered him and said, “Skin for skin! All that that man has he will give for his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: But stretch out your hand and touch his bones and his flesh, and see whether he will curse you to your face.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Yahweh said to Satan, “All right, he is in your power. Only spare his life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Satan went out from Yahweh’s presence, and he inflicted Job with loathsome skin sores from the sole of his foot up to the crown of his head.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he took for himself a potsherd with which to scrape himself, and he sat in the midst of the ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then his wife said to him, “Are you still persisting in your blamelessness? Curse God and die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to her, “You speak like one of the foolish women speaks. Indeed, should we receive the good from God, but not receive the evil?” In all this, Job did not sin with his lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus Job’s three friends heard of this calamity that had come upon him. So each set out from his own place: Eliphaz the Temanite and Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite. And they met together to come to console him and to comfort him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus they lifted up their eyes from afar, but they did not recognize him, so they raised their voice, and they wept, and each man tore his outer garment and threw dust on their heads toward the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they sat with him on the ground for seven days and seven nights, but no one spoke a word to him because they saw that his suffering was very great.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward Job opened his mouth and cursed his day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus Job spoke up and said,
speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
“Think now, who has perished who is innocent?

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
“And a word came stealing to me,

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
dread met me, and trembling,

speaker: Narrator

text:
And a spirit glided before my face;
the hair of my flesh bristled.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
‘Can a human being be more righteous than God,

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:
for he himself wounds, but he binds up;

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, we have searched this out—it is true;

text:

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
“Why do the wicked live,

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
‘God stores up his iniquity for his children’?

text:

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:
“Look, I know your thoughts

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
So how will you comfort me with emptiness,
when fraud is left in your answers?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text:
who were snatched away before their time,

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
I would lay my case before him,
and I would fill my mouth with arguments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I want to know the words with which he would answer me,

speaker: Narrator

text:
Would he contend with me in the greatness of his strength?

speaker: Narrator

text:

and I would be acquitted forever by my judge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“When I go forward, he is not there,

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
My foot has held on to his steps;

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
“But he is alone, and who can dissuade him?

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, God has made my heart faint,
and Shaddai has terrified me.
speaker: Narrator

text:

and because of me he conceals thick darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator
Narrator

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

Narrator

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

text:

text:

text:
my lips surely will not speak falseness,

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:
Look, you all have seen,

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

and he searches out the farthest limits

speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
when he made a rule for the rain

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job again took up his discourse and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
when his shining lamp was over my head—

text:
as when I was in the days of my prime,

text:
when Shaddaiwas still with me,

text:
when my paths were washed in sour milk,

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:
because I saved the needy who cried for help,

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

and I was feet to the lame.
speaker: Narrator

text:

and I investigated the stranger’s legal dispute.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I broke the evil one’s jaw bones,

speaker: Narrator

text:
“And I thought, ‘I will pass away in my nest,

speaker: Narrator

text:
My roots were open to water,
and dew spent the night on my branches;
speaker: Narrator

text:

and I was revitalized regularly.’
speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
Moreover, what use to me is the strength of their hands?

speaker: Narrator

text:
Through want and through barren hunger

speaker: Narrator

text:
They are picking salt herbs, the leaves of bushes,
and the roots of broom trees to warm themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were driven out from fellow people;
they shout at them as at a thief,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that they dwell
in holes of the ground and in the rocks.
speaker: Narrator

text:

they are gathered under the nettles.
speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

and I have become a byword for them.
speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:

speaker: Narrator

text:
and I said, ‘You shall come up to here, but you shall not go further,
and here it will set a boundary for your proud surging waves’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you ever in your life commanded the morning?
Have you made the dawn know its place,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to take hold of the earth’s skirts
so that the wicked might be shaken off from it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is changed like clay under a seal,
and they appear like a garment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And their light is withheld from the wicked,
and their uplifted arm is broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Have you entered into the sea’s sources?
Or have you walked around in the recesses of the deep?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have the gates of death been revealed to you?
Or have you seen the gates of deep shadow?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you considered closely the earth’s vast expanse?
Declare it, if you know all of it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Where then is the way where the light dwells?
And where then is its place,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that you may take it to its territory,
and that you might discern the paths to its home?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You know, for you were born then,
and the number of your days is great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you entered into the storehouses of the snow,
or have you seen the storehouses of the hail,
speaker: Narrator

text:
which I have reserved for the time of trouble,
for the day of battle and war?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where then is the way where the light is distributed,
where he scatters the east wind upon the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who has cut open a channel for the torrents
and a way for the thunder bolts,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to bring rain on a land where no one lives,
a desert where no humans live,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to satisfy desert and wasteland,
and to cause the ground to put forth the rising of grass?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is there a father for the rain,
or who fathered the drops of dew?
speaker: Narrator

text:
From whose womb did the ice come forth,
and who fathered the frost of heaven?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like stone the waters become hard,
and the faces of the deep freeze.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you bind the chains of the Pleiades,
or can you loosen the cords of Orion?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you lead forth the southern constellations at their appointed time,
or can you lead the Bear with its children?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you know heaven’s statutes,
or can you establish their rule on the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you lift up your voice to the clouds
so that a flood of water may cover you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you send forth lightnings, that they may go?
And will they say to you, ‘Here we are’?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has put wisdom in the ibis,
or who has given understanding to the rooster?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can number the clouds with wisdom?
Or who can tilt heaven’s jars,
speaker: Narrator

text:
at the flowing of the dust into a cast
and the clods cling together?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you hunt prey for the lion?
And can you satisfy the hunger of strong lions
speaker: Narrator

text:
when they are crouched in the dens,
when they lie in the thicket in an ambush?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who prepares for the crow its prey,
when its young ones cry to God for help,
and they wander around for lack of food?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you know the time when the goats of the rocks give birth?
Do you observe the doe deer’s giving birth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you number the months they fulfill,
and do you know the time of its giving birth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When they crouch, they bring forth their young ones;
they get rid of their labor pains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their young ones grow strong; they grow up in the open;
they go forth and do not return to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who has sent forth the wild ass free?
And who has released the wild donkey’s bonds,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to which I have given the wilderness as its house
and the salt flat as its dwelling place?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It scorns the city’s turmoil;
it does not hear the driver’s shouts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It explores the mountains as its pasture
and searches after every kind of green plant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Is the wild ox willing to serve you,
or will he spend the night at your feeding trough?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you tie the wild ox with its rope to a furrow,
or will it harrow the valleys after you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you trust it because its strength is great,
or will you hand your labor over to it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you rely on it that it will return your grain
and that it will gather it to your threshing floor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The wings of the female ostrich flap—
are they the pinions of the stork or the falcon?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, it leaves its eggs to the earth,
and it lets them be warmed on the ground,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and it forgets that a foot might crush an egg,
and a wild animal might trample it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It deals cruelly with its young ones, as if they were not its own,
as if without fear that its labor were in vain,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because God made it forget wisdom,
and he did not give it a share in understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When it spreads its wings aloft,
it laughs at the horse and its rider.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do you give power to the horse?
Do you clothe its neck with a mane?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you make it leap like the locust?
The majesty of its snorting is terrifying.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They paw in the valley, and it exults with strength;
it goes out to meet the battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It laughs at danger and is not dismayed,
and it does not turn back from before the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Upon it the quiver rattles
along with the flash of the spear and the short sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With roar and rage it races over the ground,
and it cannot stand still at the sound of the horn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whenever a horn sounds, it says, ‘Aha!’
And it smells the battle from a distance—
the thunder of the commanders and the war cry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Does the hawk soar by your wisdom?
Does it spread its wings to the south?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or does the eagle fly high at your command
and construct its nest high?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It lives on the rock and spends the night
on the rock point and the mountain stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From there it spies out the prey;
its eyes look from far away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And its young ones lick blood greedily,
and where the dead carcasses are, there they are.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh answered Job and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Shall a faultfinder contend with Shaddai?
Anyone who argues with God must answer it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Job answered Yahweh and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, I am insignificant.
What shall I answer you?
I lay my hand on my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Once I have spoken, and I will not answer;
even twice, but I will not proceed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh answered Job from the storm, and he said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Prepare yourself for a difficult task like a man,
and I will question you, and you shall declare to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Indeed, would you annul my justice?
Would you condemn me, so that you might be righteous?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or do you have an arm like God,
and can you thunder with a voice like his?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Adorn yourself with pride and dignity,
and clothe yourself with splendor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pour out the overflowing of your anger,
and look at all the proud, and humble them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look at all the proud, humble them,
and tread down the wicked where they stand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hide them in the dust together;
bind their faces in the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I will also praise you,
that your own right hand can save you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, Behemoth, which I have made just as I made you;
it eats grass like the ox.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, its strength is in its loins
and its power in the muscles of its stomach.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It keeps its tail straight like a cedar;
the sinews of its thighs are tightly wound.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its bones are tubes of copper,
its limbs like rods of iron.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“It is the first of God’s actions;
the one who made him furnishes it with his sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, the mountains yield produce for it,
and all wild animals play there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Under the lotus tree it lies,
in the hiding place of the reeds and in the marsh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lotus trees cover it with their shade;
the wadi’s poplar trees surround it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, if the river is turbulent, it is not frightened;
it is confident even though the Jordan rushes against its mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can anyone take it by its eyes?
Can he pierce its nose with a snare?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Can you draw out Leviathan with a fishhook?
Or can you tie down its mouth with a cord?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you put a rope in its nose?
Or can you pierce its jawbone with a hook?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will it make numerous pleas for mercy to you?
Or will it speak gentle words to you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will it make a covenant with you?
Will you take it as a slave forever?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you play with it as with birds
and put it on a leash for your girls?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will guildsmen bargain over it?
Will they divide it between tradesmen?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can you fill its kin with harpoons
or its head with fish spears?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lay your hands on it;
think about the battle—you will not do it again!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, the hope of capturing it is false.
Will one be hurled down even at its sight?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it not fierce when somebody stirs it?
Who then is he who would stand before it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has come to confront me, that I should repay him?
Under all the heavens, it belongs to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will not keep quiet concerning its limbs
or concerning the extent of its might and the gracefulness of its frame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can strip off its outer covering?
Who can penetrate its double harness?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can open the doors of its face?
Its teeth all around are fearsome.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its back has scales of shields;
it is shut up closely as with a seal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are close to one another—
even the air cannot come between them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are joined one to another;
they cling together and cannot be separated.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Its snorting flashes forth light,
and its eyes are red like dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Torches go from its mouth;
sparks of fire shoot out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Smoke comes from its nostrils
as from a kettle boiling and burning bulrushes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its breath kindles charcoal,
and a flame comes from its mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Strength abides in its neck,
and dismay dances before it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its flesh’s folds of skin cling together;
it is cast on it—it will not be moved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its heart is cast as stone;
yes, it is cast as the lower millstone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When it raises itself, the mighty ones are terrified;
they retreat because of its thrashing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Reaching it with the sword does not avail,
nor with the spear, the dart, or the javelin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It regards iron as straw,
bronze as rotten wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An arrow will not make it flee;
sling stones are turned to stubble for it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Clubs are regarded as stubble,
and it laughs at the short sword’s rattle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Its underparts are shards of a potsherd;
it moves over mud like a threshing sledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It makes the deep boil like a cooking pot;
it makes the sea like a pot of ointment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behind it, it leaves a glistening wake;
one would think that the deep has gray hair.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“On the ground it has no equal—
a creature without fear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It observes all the lofty;
it is king over all that are proud.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered Yahweh and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I know that you can do all things,
and any scheme from you will not be thwarted.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
‘Hear and I will speak;
I will question you, then inform me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the ear’s hearing I heard of you,
but now my eye has seen you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I despise myself
and repent in dust and ashes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And then after Yahweh spoke these words to Job, Yahweh said to Eliphaz the Temanite, “My wrath has been kindled against you and against the two of your friends, for you have not spoken to me what is right as my servant Job has.
speaker: Narrator

text: So then, take for yourselves seven bulls and seven rams, and go to my servant Job and offer a burnt offering for yourselves. And my servant Job will pray for you, for I will certainly accept his prayer, so that it will not be done with you according to your folly, for you have not spoken to me what is right as my servant Job has.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Eliphaz the Temanite and Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite went and did just as Yahweh had told them, and Yahweh accepted Job’s prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Yahweh returned Job’s fortune when he prayed to him on behalf of his friends. Thus Yahweh increased all that Job had twice as much as before.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all his brothers and all his sisters and all those who had known him before came to him, and they ate bread with him in his house and showed sympathy to him and comforted him for all the disaster that Yahweh had brought upon him. Then each one gave to him one piece of money, and each one gave to him one ornamental ring of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Yahweh blessed Job’s latter days more than his beginning. Thus he had fourteen thousand sheep and goats and six thousand camels and a thousand pair of oxen and a thousand female donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he had seven sons and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he called the name of the first Jemimah and the name of the second Keziah and the name of the third Qeren-Happuk.
speaker: Narrator

text: And beautiful women were not found in all the land like Job’s daughters, and their father gave to them an inheritance in the midst of their brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job lived after this one hundred and forty years, and he saw his sons and his grandsons for four generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job died old and full of days.
speaker: Narrator
